name: Pythagorean identity for sine and cosine
explanation: The fundamental trigonometric identity stating that the square of cosine plus the square of sine of an angle equals one.

name: Sine rule for triangle side ratios
explanation: A formula relating the ratios of sides of a triangle to the sines of their opposite angles.

name: Cosine rule for triangle side lengths
explanation: A formula that relates the lengths of sides of a triangle to the cosine of one of its angles, useful for finding unknown sides or angles.

name: Cosine of angle difference formula
explanation: An identity expressing the cosine of the difference between two angles in terms of the cosines and sines of the individual angles.

name: Cosine of angle sum formula
explanation: An identity expressing the cosine of the sum of two angles in terms of the cosines and sines of the individual angles.

name: Double angle formula for cosine (cos 2A)
explanation: An identity expressing the cosine of twice an angle as the difference of the squares of cosine and sine of the angle.

name: Sine of angle sum formula
explanation: An identity expressing the sine of the sum of two angles in terms of the sines and cosines of the individual angles.

name: Sine of angle difference formula
explanation: An identity expressing the sine of the difference between two angles in terms of the sines and cosines of the individual angles.

name: Tangent of angle sum formula
explanation: An identity expressing the tangent of the sum of two angles in terms of the tangents of the individual angles.
broader_concept: Angle addition and subtraction formulas for tangent

name: Tangent of angle difference formula
explanation: An identity expressing the tangent of the difference between two angles in terms of the tangents of the individual angles.
broader_concept: Angle addition and subtraction formulas for tangent

name: Double angle formula for sine (sin 2A)
explanation: An identity expressing the sine of twice an angle as twice the product of sine and cosine of the angle.

name: Double angle formula for tangent (tan 2A)
explanation: An identity expressing the tangent of twice an angle in terms of the tangent of the angle.

name: Cosine squared in terms of cosine double angle
explanation: An identity expressing the square of cosine of an angle as half the sum of one and the cosine of twice the angle.

name: Sine squared in terms of cosine double angle
explanation: An identity expressing the square of sine of an angle as half the difference of one and the cosine of twice the angle.

name: Product-to-sum formula for 2 cos A cos B
explanation: An identity expressing twice the product of cosines of two angles as the sum of cosines of their sum and difference.

name: Product-to-sum formula for 2 sin A cos B
explanation: An identity expressing twice the product of sine of one angle and cosine of another as the sum of sines of their sum and difference.

name: Product-to-sum formula for 2 sin A sin B
explanation: An identity expressing twice the product of sines of two angles as the difference of cosines of their difference and sum.

name: Product-to-sum formula for 2 cos A sin B
explanation: An identity expressing twice the product of cosine of one angle and sine of another as the difference of sines of their sum and difference.

name: Sum-to-product formula for cos A + cos B
explanation: An identity expressing the sum of cosines of two angles as twice the product of cosines of half their sum and half their difference.

name: Sum-to-product formula for cos A – cos B
explanation: An identity expressing the difference of cosines of two angles as negative twice the product of sines of half their sum and half their difference.

name: Sum-to-product formula for sin A + sin B
explanation: An identity expressing the sum of sines of two angles as twice the product of sines of half their sum and cosines of half their difference.

name: Sum-to-product formula for sin A – sin B
explanation: An identity expressing the difference of sines of two angles as twice the product of cosines of half their sum and sines of half their difference.

name: circle drawing with given radius

name: use of straight edge in geometric constructions

name: use of compass in geometric constructions
explanation: Using a compass to draw arcs and circles with precision in geometric diagrams.

name: use of ruler in geometric constructions
explanation: Applying a ruler to measure lengths and draw straight lines in geometric diagrams.

name: use of protractor in geometric constructions
explanation: Using a protractor to measure and construct specific angles in geometric diagrams.

name: use of set square in geometric constructions
explanation: Employing a set square to draw perpendicular and parallel lines accurately in geometric diagrams.

name: coordinating the plane

name: representing linear relationships in tabular form

name: representing linear relationships in graphical form

name: interpretation of start value in linear relationships

name: point of intersection of two linear relationships

name: strategies for solving systems of two linear equations

name: Pythagorean theorem application in right-angled triangles
explanation: Using the relation a² + b² = c² to solve problems involving lengths in right-angled triangles, including heights and distances.

name: use of trigonometric ratios in right-angled triangles
explanation: Applying sine, cosine, and tangent ratios to find unknown sides or angles in right-angled triangles in real-world contexts.

name: identification of axes of symmetry in simple shapes
explanation: Locating lines through shapes that divide them into mirror-image halves.

name: recognition of images under translation
explanation: Understanding how points and objects shift uniformly in a given direction and distance without rotation or reflection.

name: recognition of images under central symmetry
explanation: Identifying points and objects reflected through a central point producing an image rotated 180 degrees about that point.

name: recognition of images under axial symmetry
explanation: Identifying points and objects reflected across a line (axis of symmetry) producing mirror images.

name: recognition of images under rotation
explanation: Understanding how points and objects are turned about a fixed point through a specified angle and direction.

name: investigation of enlargements and area effects
explanation: Studying how enlargements with a given centre and scale factor affect the size and area of shapes, including scale factors less than 1 and greater than 1 (rational numbers).

name: performing geometric constructions 16-21
explanation: Executing specific geometric constructions numbered 16 through 21 as per referenced curriculum materials.

name: use of logic and deductive reasoning terms
explanation: Understanding and applying terms such as theorem, proof, axiom, corollary, converse, implies, is equivalent to, if and only if, and proof by contradiction in geometric reasoning.

name: investigation and proof of theorems related to ratios
explanation: Studying and proving theorems concerning ratios that underpin the Pythagorean theorem and other geometric results.

name: use of slope to determine parallelism
explanation: Using the equality of slopes to establish that two lines are parallel.

name: use of slope to determine perpendicularity
explanation: Using the negative reciprocal relationship of slopes to establish that two lines are perpendicular.

name: recognition of linear equation in standard form
explanation: Understanding that equations of the form ax + by + c = 0 represent straight lines in the coordinate plane.

name: calculation of triangle area using coordinates
explanation: Finding the area of a triangle given the coordinates of its vertices using coordinate geometry formulas.

name: equation of a circle in center-radius form
explanation: Using the equation (x - h)² + (y - k)² = r² to represent all points on a circle with center (h, k) and radius r.

name: equation of a circle in general form
explanation: Understanding the equation x² + y² + 2gx + 2fy + c = 0 as representing a circle with center (-g, -f) and radius r = √(g² + f² - c).

name: solving problems involving line and circle intersections
explanation: Finding points of intersection between a line and a circle, including cases where the circle is centered at the origin.

name: perpendicular distance from a point to a line
explanation: Calculating the shortest distance between a given point and a line in the plane using coordinate geometry.

name: angle between two lines
explanation: Determining the measure of the angle formed where two lines intersect using their slopes.

name: internal division of a line segment in ratio m:n
explanation: Finding the coordinates of a point that divides a line segment internally into two parts with lengths in the ratio m:n.

name: use of Pythagorean theorem in 2D problem solving
explanation: Applying the Pythagorean theorem specifically to two-dimensional geometric problems involving right-angled triangles.

name: trigonometric calculation of triangle area
explanation: Using trigonometric ratios and formulas such as 1/2 ab sin C to calculate the area of a triangle.

name: application of sine rule in triangle problems
explanation: Using the sine rule to find unknown sides or angles in any triangle based on ratios of sides to sines of opposite angles.

name: application of cosine rule in triangle problems
explanation: Using the cosine rule to find unknown sides or angles in any triangle based on side lengths and included angles.

name: definition of sine and cosine for all angle values
explanation: Extending the definitions of sine and cosine functions beyond acute angles to all real values of θ, including negative and greater than 360° angles.

name: definition of tangent function
explanation: Defining the tangent function as the ratio of sine to cosine for any angle θ where cosine is not zero.

name: calculation of sector area of a circle
explanation: Using trigonometry and circle formulas to find the area of a sector defined by a central angle in a circle.

name: calculation of arc length of a circle
explanation: Determining the length of an arc corresponding to a given central angle in a circle using radian measure.

name: working with trigonometric ratios in surd form
explanation: Expressing trigonometric ratios exactly using square roots and irrational numbers instead of decimal approximations.

name: solving 3D trigonometry problems
explanation: Applying trigonometric principles to solve problems involving three-dimensional geometric figures.

name: graphing sine function
explanation: Plotting the sine function y = sin θ over a range of angle values to visualize its periodic behavior.

name: graphing cosine function
explanation: Plotting the cosine function y = cos θ over a range of angle values to visualize its periodic behavior.

name: graphing tangent function
explanation: Plotting the tangent function y = tan θ over a range of angle values, noting its periodicity and asymptotes.

name: graphing trigonometric functions of form f(θ) = a + b sin cθ
explanation: Plotting sine functions with amplitude, vertical shift, and frequency modifications represented by parameters a, b, and c.

name: graphing trigonometric functions of form g(θ) = a + b cos cθ
explanation: Plotting cosine functions with amplitude, vertical shift, and frequency modifications represented by parameters a, b, and c.

name: solving trigonometric equations sin nθ = 0
explanation: Finding all angle solutions θ that satisfy the equation sin nθ = 0 for integer n, including general solutions.

name: solving trigonometric equations cos nθ = 1/2
explanation: Finding all angle solutions θ that satisfy the equation cos nθ = 1/2 for integer n, including general solutions.

name: use of radian measure of angles
explanation: Measuring angles in radians, where one radian is the angle subtended by an arc equal in length to the radius of the circle.

name: derivation of fundamental trigonometric formulae
explanation: Proving key trigonometric identities and formulae that relate sine, cosine, tangent, and their combinations.

name: application of trigonometric formulae 1-24
explanation: Using a comprehensive set of trigonometric identities and formulae to solve various problems in trigonometry.

name: irrational numbers
explanation: Numbers that cannot be expressed as a ratio of two integers and have non-repeating, non-terminating decimal expansions.

name: complex numbers
explanation: Numbers consisting of a real part and an imaginary part, expressed in the form a + bi where i is the imaginary unit.

name: division of complex numbers
explanation: The process of dividing one complex number by another, often involving multiplication by the conjugate to rationalize the denominator.

name: equality of complex numbers
explanation: Two complex numbers are equal if and only if their corresponding real parts and imaginary parts are equal.

name: Argand diagram representation of complex numbers
explanation: A graphical representation of complex numbers on a plane with the horizontal axis as the real part and the vertical axis as the imaginary part.

name: modulus of a complex number
explanation: The distance of a complex number from the origin in the Argand diagram, calculated as the square root of the sum of squares of its real and imaginary parts.

name: transformations of complex numbers
explanation: Operations such as translation, rotation, and scaling applied to complex numbers represented on the Argand diagram.

name: conjugate roots theorem
explanation: A theorem stating that non-real roots of polynomials with real coefficients occur in conjugate pairs.

name: polar form of a complex number
explanation: Representation of a complex number using its modulus and argument as r(cos θ + i sin θ).

name: products of complex numbers in polar form
explanation: Multiplying complex numbers by multiplying their moduli and adding their arguments.

name: quotients of complex numbers in polar form
explanation: Dividing complex numbers by dividing their moduli and subtracting their arguments.

name: De Moivre’s theorem
explanation: A formula that expresses powers of complex numbers in polar form as r^n (cos nθ + i sin nθ).

name: applications of De Moivre’s theorem
explanation: Using De Moivre’s theorem to find powers and roots of complex numbers and solve trigonometric identities.

name: enlargements in geometry
explanation: Transformations that scale figures by a scale factor relative to a fixed point, changing size but preserving shape.

name: geometric constructions
explanation: Methods of drawing geometric figures accurately using tools like compass and straightedge.

name: antidifferentiation

name: integration of exponential functions

name: integration of trigonometric functions

name: applications of integration

name: definite integrals

name: finding areas by integration

name: average value of a function

name: tangents and increasing/decreasing functions

name: stationary points

name: graphs of the derived (slope) function

name: 3-dimensional objects

explanation: A numerical method to approximate the area under a curve by dividing it into trapezoids.

name: tree diagrams for probability

name: probability distributions: expected value
explanation: The weighted average of all possible values of a random variable, representing its mean outcome.

name: Bernoulli trials and binomial distribution
explanation: Experiments with two possible outcomes repeated independently, modeled by the binomial distribution.

name: independence of events in probability
explanation: Two events are independent if the occurrence of one does not affect the probability of the other.

name: probability involving permutations and combinations

name: probability simulations

name: introduction to functions

name: composition of functions

name: types of functions

name: inverse functions

name: sketching graphs of functions
explanation: Plotting the shape and key features of functions based on their algebraic expressions.

name: exponential functions
explanation: Functions where the variable is in the exponent, typically of the form f(x) = a^x.

name: logarithmic functions

name: related graphs

name: scatter diagrams

name: measuring correlation: line of best fit
explanation: Determining the strength and direction of a linear relationship between variables using a fitted line.

name: normal distribution

name: normal probability distributions

name: hypothesis testing for population proportion

name: sampling distribution of the mean

name: confidence interval for a population mean

name: complex numbers in rectangular form

name: complex conjugate

name: sum of finite geometric series

name: representing numbers as cubes and cube roots
explanation: Expressing numbers in the form of cubes (powers of 3) and their corresponding cube roots.

name: representing numbers as reciprocals
explanation: Expressing numbers as the multiplicative inverse, i.e., 1 divided by the number.

name: rules of indices: product rule
explanation: For the same base, multiplying powers adds their exponents: a^p × a^q = a^(p+q).

name: rules of indices: quotient rule
explanation: For the same base, dividing powers subtracts their exponents: a^p / a^q = a^(p−q).

name: rules of indices: zero exponent rule
explanation: Any non-zero base raised to the zero power equals one: a^0 = 1.

name: rules of indices: power of a power
explanation: Raising a power to another power multiplies the exponents: (a^p)^q = a^(pq).

name: rules of indices: negative exponents
explanation: A negative exponent represents the reciprocal of the positive exponent: a^(−p) = 1 / a^p.

name: rules of indices: product to a power
explanation: A product raised to a power equals the product of each factor raised to that power: (ab)^p = a^p b^p.

name: rules of indices: quotient to a power
explanation: A quotient raised to a power equals the quotient of each term raised to that power: (a/b)^p = a^p / b^p.

name: logarithm product rule
explanation: The logarithm of a product is the sum of the logarithms: log_a(xy) = log_a x + log_a y.

name: logarithm quotient rule
explanation: The logarithm of a quotient is the difference of the logarithms: log_a(x/y) = log_a x − log_a y.

name: logarithm power rule
explanation: The logarithm of a power is the exponent times the logarithm: log_a(x^q) = q log_a x.

name: logarithm of base and one
explanation: log_a a = 1 and log_a 1 = 0 for any valid base a.

name: change of base formula for logarithms
explanation: Expressing logarithms in terms of logs with a different base: log_a x = log_b x / log_b a.

explanation: Numbers expressed as multiples of i, where i is defined as the square root of -1.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Definition and properties of the imaginary unit i
explanation: The imaginary unit i satisfies i² = -1 and is used to define imaginary and complex numbers.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Real and imaginary parts of a complex number
explanation: The components a and b in a complex number a + bi, representing the real and imaginary parts respectively.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Addition of complex numbers in rectangular form
explanation: Adding complex numbers by separately adding their real parts and their imaginary parts.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Subtraction of complex numbers in rectangular form
explanation: Subtracting complex numbers by separately subtracting their real parts and their imaginary parts.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Multiplication of complex numbers in rectangular form
explanation: Multiplying complex numbers using distributive property and simplifying using i² = -1.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Complex conjugate of a complex number
explanation: For a complex number a + bi, its conjugate is a - bi, used to simplify division of complex numbers.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Division of complex numbers using conjugates
explanation: Dividing complex numbers by multiplying numerator and denominator by the conjugate of the denominator to rationalize it.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Multiplying a complex number by a real scalar
explanation: Scaling both the real and imaginary parts of a complex number by a real number, resulting in stretching or contraction in the Argand plane.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Reflection of a complex number through the origin
explanation: Multiplying a complex number by -1, which reflects it across the origin in the Argand diagram.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Translation of complex numbers in the Argand plane
explanation: Adding a fixed complex number to other complex numbers, resulting in a translation of their points in the complex plane.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Parallelogram law for addition of complex numbers
explanation: The geometric interpretation that the sum of two complex numbers corresponds to the diagonal of the parallelogram formed by their points and the origin.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Rotation of a complex number by multiplication by i
explanation: Multiplying a complex number by i rotates it 90 degrees anticlockwise about the origin in the Argand plane.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Rotation of a complex number by powers of i
explanation: Multiplying a complex number by iⁿ rotates it by 90° × n anticlockwise about the origin in the Argand plane.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Conjugate roots theorem for polynomials with real coefficients
explanation: If a polynomial with real coefficients has a complex root z, then its conjugate z̅ is also a root.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Modulus and argument of a complex number
explanation: The modulus is the distance from the origin; the argument is the angle the line from the origin to the point makes with the positive real axis.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Principal value of the argument
explanation: The unique value of the argument of a complex number restricted to the interval (-π, π].
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Multiplication of complex numbers in polar form
explanation: The product of two complex numbers has modulus equal to the product of the moduli and argument equal to the sum of the arguments.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Division of complex numbers in polar form
explanation: The quotient of two complex numbers has modulus equal to the quotient of the moduli and argument equal to the difference of the arguments.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Proof of de Moivre’s theorem by mathematical induction
explanation: A stepwise proof showing the theorem holds for n=1, assuming true for n=k, then proving for n=k+1.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Application of de Moivre’s theorem to powers of complex numbers
explanation: Using the theorem to simplify expressions of complex numbers raised to integer powers in polar form.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Finding nth roots of complex numbers using polar form
explanation: Expressing the nth roots of a complex number by applying de Moivre’s theorem with fractional exponents and adding multiples of 2π to the argument.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: General polar form of a complex number
explanation: Expressing a complex number as r[cos(θ + 2nπ) + i sin(θ + 2nπ)] to account for periodicity in trigonometric functions.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Scale factor in enlargements
explanation: The ratio by which lengths are multiplied to produce an enlargement of a figure.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Centre of enlargement
explanation: The fixed point about which a figure is enlarged or reduced.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Constructing an enlargement of a figure
explanation: Drawing lines from the centre of enlargement through each vertex and extending or contracting them by the scale factor to find the image vertices.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Enlargement with scale factor less than 1 (reduction)
explanation: An enlargement where the scale factor is between 0 and 1, resulting in a smaller image closer to the centre of enlargement.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Finding the centre of enlargement from an object and image
explanation: Locating the centre by joining corresponding points of the object and image and finding their intersection.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Effect of enlargement on area
explanation: The area of an enlarged figure is multiplied by the square of the scale factor.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Bisecting a line segment
explanation: Constructing the perpendicular bisector of a line segment to find its midpoint.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Bisecting an angle
explanation: Constructing a line that divides an angle into two equal parts using compass arcs.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Constructing an angle of 60 degrees
explanation: Using compass arcs to create an equilateral triangle and thereby construct a 60° angle.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Constructing a tangent to a circle at a given point
explanation: Drawing a line perpendicular to the radius at the point on the circle to form the tangent.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Constructing a parallelogram given side lengths and angle
explanation: Using a base, angle measurement, and compass arcs to construct a parallelogram with specified dimensions.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Constructing the circumcircle of a triangle
explanation: Finding the circumcentre by intersecting perpendicular bisectors of sides and drawing a circle through the vertices.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Constructing the incircle of a triangle
explanation: Finding the incentre by intersecting angle bisectors and drawing a circle tangent to all sides.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Constructing the centroid of a triangle
explanation: Finding the point of concurrency of the medians, which are lines from vertices to midpoints of opposite sides.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Constructing the orthocentre of a triangle
explanation: Finding the point of concurrency of the altitudes, which are perpendiculars from vertices to opposite sides.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Median of a triangle
explanation: A line segment joining a vertex to the midpoint of the opposite side.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Altitude of a triangle
explanation: A perpendicular segment from a vertex to the opposite side or its extension.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Pythagoras’ theorem applied to line construction
explanation: Using the relation a² + b² = c² to construct line segments of length √2 and other irrationals.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Antidifferentiation (integration) of power functions
explanation: Finding the original function given its derivative, typically by increasing the power by one and dividing by the new power.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Constant of integration
explanation: An arbitrary constant added to the antiderivative since differentiation of a constant is zero.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Integration of sine and cosine functions
explanation: Integrals of sin(ax) and cos(ax) are (-1/a)cos(ax) + c and (1/a)sin(ax) + c respectively.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Application of integration to displacement, velocity, and acceleration
explanation: Using integration to find velocity from acceleration and displacement from velocity in motion problems.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Definite integral as area under a curve
explanation: The definite integral of a function between two limits gives the net area between the curve and the x-axis over that interval.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Indefinite integral
explanation: An integral without specified limits representing a family of antiderivatives including a constant of integration.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Limits of integration
explanation: The lower and upper bounds a and b in a definite integral ∫_a^b f(x) dx.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Area between two curves
explanation: The area enclosed between two functions f(x) and g(x) over an interval is given by the integral of their difference.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Average value of a function over an interval
explanation: The height of a rectangle over the interval [a,b] with the same area as under the curve, calculated as (1/(b-a)) ∫_a^b f(x) dx.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Equation of tangent to a curve at a point
explanation: Using the derivative to find the slope at a point and applying point-slope form to find the tangent line equation.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Increasing and decreasing functions via first derivative
explanation: A function is increasing where its derivative is positive and decreasing where its derivative is negative.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Local maximum and minimum points
explanation: Stationary points where the function attains a local highest or lowest value respectively.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Second derivative test for turning points
explanation: Using the sign of the second derivative at a stationary point to determine if it is a local maximum (negative) or minimum (positive).
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Point of inflection
explanation: A point on the curve where concavity changes and the second derivative is zero, often where the tangent crosses the curve.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Slope function (derived function) graph
explanation: The graph of the derivative of a function, showing the slope of the original function at each point.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Maximum and minimum problems using calculus
explanation: Using differentiation and second derivative test to find and classify maxima and minima in applied problems.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Related rates of change problems
explanation: Problems involving rates of change of related variables, solved using the chain rule of differentiation.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Chain rule for related rates
explanation: Differentiation rule stating that dy/dx = dy/du × du/dx for composite functions, used in related rates problems.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Geometric series
explanation: A sequence where each term is found by multiplying the previous term by a constant ratio.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Compound interest formula
explanation: Calculating accumulated amount with interest added to principal periodically, using A = P(1 + i)^t.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Annual Percentage Rate (APR) and Annual Equivalent Rate (AER)
explanation: APR is the true annual interest rate charged for borrowing; AER is the effective annual rate paid on investments.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Present value in compound interest
explanation: Calculating the current worth of a future sum of money discounted at a compound interest rate.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Straight line depreciation
explanation: Asset value decreases by a fixed amount each year over its useful life.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Reducing balance depreciation
explanation: Asset value decreases by a fixed percentage of its current value each year.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Instalment savings as geometric series
explanation: Accumulated value of regular payments with compound interest, represented as a sum of geometric series terms.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Pension present value calculation
explanation: Calculating the lump sum needed now to provide fixed periodic payments in the future, using geometric series.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Loan and mortgage repayment formula
explanation: Formula to calculate fixed periodic repayments on a loan or mortgage using present value of an annuity.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Properties of squares
explanation: Quadrilaterals with four equal sides, four right angles, and diagonals that bisect perpendicularly.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Properties of rectangles
explanation: Quadrilaterals with opposite sides equal, four right angles, and equal diagonals that bisect each other.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Properties of parallelograms
explanation: Quadrilaterals with opposite sides equal and parallel, opposite angles equal, and diagonals that bisect each other.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Area formulas for trapeziums
explanation: Area calculated as half the sum of the lengths of parallel sides multiplied by the height.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Regular polygons and interior angles
explanation: Polygons with equal sides and angles, with interior angles depending on the number of sides.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Length of arc of a circle
explanation: The length of a circular arc calculated as a fraction of the circumference based on the central angle in degrees or radians.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Area of a sector of a circle
explanation: Area of a sector calculated as a fraction of the circle's area based on the central angle in degrees or radians.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Volume and surface area of prisms
explanation: Volume is the product of the base area and length; surface area is sum of areas of all faces.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Volume and surface area of cylinders
explanation: Volume is πr²h; surface area includes areas of two circular bases and the curved surface.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Volume and surface area of cones
explanation: Volume is one-third of base area times height; surface area includes base and lateral surface area.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Volume and surface area of spheres and hemispheres
explanation: Volume of sphere is (4/3)πr³; hemisphere is half; surface area of sphere is 4πr²; hemisphere is 3πr².
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Percentage error calculation
explanation: The relative difference between an estimated and true value expressed as a percentage of the true value.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Tolerance in measurement
explanation: The allowable deviation from a measured value, typically half the smallest unit of the measuring instrument.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Degrees of accuracy
explanation: The precision to which a measurement is recorded, affecting the possible range of the true value.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Trapezoidal rule for numerical integration
explanation: Approximating the area under a curve by dividing it into trapeziums and summing their areas.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Probability distributions for discrete random variables
explanation: A table or function assigning probabilities to each possible discrete outcome of a random variable.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Expected value of a discrete random variable
explanation: The weighted average of all possible values of a random variable, weighted by their probabilities.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Bernoulli trials
explanation: Repeated independent trials with two possible outcomes (success or failure) and constant probability of success.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Binomial distribution
explanation: Probability distribution giving the probability of k successes in n Bernoulli trials.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Multiplication rule for independent events
explanation: The probability of two independent events both occurring is the product of their individual probabilities.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Permutations and combinations in probability
explanation: Counting methods to determine the number of ways events can occur, used to calculate probabilities.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Probability of events occurring at least once
explanation: Calculating the probability that an event occurs one or more times by subtracting the probability of it never occurring from 1.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Ordered pairs and relations
explanation: Pairs of elements (x, y) representing inputs and outputs in a relation between two sets.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Domain and range of a relation
explanation: Domain is the set of all input values; range is the set of all output values in a relation.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Mapping diagrams for functions
explanation: Visual representation showing how each element of the domain maps to an element of the range.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Definition of a function
explanation: A relation where each input has exactly one unique output.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Codomain of a function
explanation: The set of possible output values specified for a function, which may be larger than the actual range.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Domain intervals and restricted domains
explanation: Limiting the domain of a function to intervals where it behaves as a function or to avoid undefined values.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Vertical line test
explanation: A graphical method to determine if a curve represents a function by checking if any vertical line intersects it more than once.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Non-commutativity of function composition
explanation: In general, composing functions in different orders yields different results, i.e., g ◦ f ≠ f ◦ g.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Injective (one-to-one) functions
explanation: Functions where each output corresponds to exactly one input; no two inputs map to the same output.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Horizontal line test for injectivity
explanation: A function is injective if every horizontal line intersects its graph at most once.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Surjective (onto) functions
explanation: Functions where every element of the codomain is an output of the function.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Horizontal line test for surjectivity
explanation: A function is surjective if every horizontal line intersects its graph at least once.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Bijective functions
explanation: Functions that are both injective and surjective, establishing a one-to-one correspondence between domain and codomain.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Finding inverse functions algebraically
explanation: Solving the equation y = f(x) for x in terms of y and then interchanging variables to find f⁻¹(x).
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Restricted domain for invertibility
explanation: Limiting the domain of a non-injective function to make it bijective and thus invertible.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Sketching graphs of linear functions
explanation: Plotting straight lines by finding intercepts and using slope.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Sketching graphs of quadratic functions
explanation: Plotting parabolas using intercepts, vertex (turning point), and axis of symmetry.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Completed square form of quadratic functions
explanation: Rewriting quadratics in the form y = a(x - p)² + q to identify vertex and graph shape.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Sketching graphs of cubic functions
explanation: Plotting cubic curves by finding intercepts and locating turning points.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Double root and its graphical significance
explanation: A root where the graph touches but does not cross the x-axis, corresponding to a turning point.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Graphs of exponential functions with base greater than 1
explanation: Increasing curves crossing y-axis at 1 and approaching x-axis as asymptote for negative x.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Graphs of exponential functions with base between 0 and 1
explanation: Decreasing curves crossing y-axis at 1 and approaching x-axis as asymptote for positive x.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Logarithmic functions as inverses of exponential functions
explanation: Functions defined as inverses of exponentials, with domain positive real numbers and range all real numbers.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Graph of natural logarithm function
explanation: Increasing curve with vertical asymptote at x=0, domain (0, ∞), range (-∞, ∞).
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Transformations of function graphs: vertical translation
explanation: Adding or subtracting a constant to a function shifts its graph up or down.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Transformations of function graphs: horizontal translation
explanation: Replacing x by x ± a shifts the graph left or right by a units.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Reflection of function graphs about axes
explanation: Multiplying function by -1 reflects graph about x-axis; replacing x by -x reflects about y-axis.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Vertical stretching and compression of function graphs
explanation: Multiplying function by a constant scales the graph vertically, stretching if >1 and compressing if between 0 and 1.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Scatter diagrams for bivariate data
explanation: Graphs plotting pairs of data points to identify relationships between two variables.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Correlation between variables
explanation: Measure of the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two variables.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Positive, negative, and no correlation
explanation: Positive correlation means variables increase together; negative means one increases as the other decreases; no correlation means no linear relationship.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Causal relationship versus correlation
explanation: Causal relationship implies one variable causes change in another, while correlation only indicates association.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Correlation coefficient (r)
explanation: A numerical measure between -1 and 1 indicating the strength and direction of a linear relationship.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Product-moment correlation coefficient calculation
explanation: A method to compute the correlation coefficient based on sums of products of paired data deviations.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Line of best fit
explanation: A straight line that best represents the trend of data points in a scatter diagram, minimizing distances from points to the line.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Equation of line of best fit
explanation: Linear equation y = A + Bx representing the line of best fit, where B is slope and A is y-intercept.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Empirical Rule for normal distribution
explanation: Approximately 68%, 95%, and 99.7% of data lie within 1, 2, and 3 standard deviations of the mean respectively.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Standard score (z-score)
explanation: The number of standard deviations a data point is from the mean, calculated as (x - μ)/σ.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Standard normal distribution (Z distribution)
explanation: A normal distribution with mean 0 and standard deviation 1 used for standardizing scores.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Using standard normal tables to find probabilities
explanation: Tables giving the area under the standard normal curve up to a given z-score, used to find probabilities.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Margin of error approximation for proportions
explanation: Approximate margin of error calculated as 1/√n for a 95% confidence level.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Standard error of sample proportion
explanation: Estimated standard deviation of the sampling distribution of the sample proportion, calculated as sqrt(p(1-p)/n).
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Standard error of the mean
explanation: The standard deviation of the sampling distribution of the mean, calculated as population standard deviation divided by square root of sample size.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Confidence interval for population mean
explanation: Interval estimate for the population mean based on sample mean, standard error, and confidence level.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Hypothesis testing for population mean
explanation: Testing claims about a population mean using sample data, test statistics, and critical regions at a given significance level.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Test statistic for hypothesis testing of mean
explanation: Standardized value calculated as (sample mean - population mean) divided by standard error, used to decide on hypothesis rejection.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Critical region and critical values
explanation: Ranges of test statistic values where the null hypothesis is rejected, defined by significance level and critical values.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: p-value in hypothesis testing
explanation: The probability of obtaining a test statistic as extreme as the observed one, used to assess evidence against the null hypothesis.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: polynomial expression with positive integer powers

name: linear polynomial expression
explanation: A polynomial expression where the highest power of the variable is 1, representing a straight-line relationship.
